source.citation: Peterson, J.T. 1987. Survey of Mechanized Processing Equipment: Evaluation of the Caterpillar DL221 Processor. FERIC Technical Note TN-103.
notes: Coastal old-growth study (MacMillan Bloedel Northwest Bay Division, Vancouver Island) with Caterpillar DL221 processor handling Madill 084 grapple-yarded windrows in January 1987.

Area A windrows were feller-bunched with butts toward the road on level ground; Area B windrows were hand-felled below road grade with dirt banks and misaligned tops, resulting in slower cycles and higher costs.
FERIC recorded low observed utilisation (52.6%) due to mechanical tweaks; analysis includes an achievable 73% utilisation scenario once the recommended modifications are in place.

scenarios.name: area_a_feller_bunched
scenarios.description: Feller-bunched, grapple-yarded windrows (butts facing road, level ground, no dirt bank).
notes: Windrow prep aligned stems and avoided dirt banks, so truck loading and processor slewing were efficient.
Use when windrows are prepared by bunchers or live-heel loaders with butts oriented to the road.

scenarios.name: area_b_handfelled
scenarios.description: Hand-felled windrows below the road grade with dirt banks and tops toward traffic.
notes: Dirt banks and misaligned stems forced extra swing/handling time; cedar logs up to 1.5 m diameter were present in the piles.
Use when roadside prep is poor or windrows sit below grade, requiring more swing time and cleanup.

scenarios.name: combined_observed
scenarios.description: Observed average across Areas A and B at 52.6% utilisation (study baseline).
notes: Matches the five-day monitored average cited in the TN-103 summary (26 trees/PMH, 20.4 m³/SMH).
Cost basis excludes supervision/overhead and interest, mirroring the original FERIC analysis.

scenarios.name: combined_high_util
scenarios.description: FERIC’s achievable utilisation scenario (73%) once DL221 modifications and windrow prep improvements are implemented.
notes: Shift-level production increases to 226 m³/8 h with the recommended boom-level monitor fix, engine cover clamps, and saw-bar upgrades.
Cost per tree assumes the combined average stem volume (1.48 m³) noted in Table 2.
